name: #01_p_tr1
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for payment.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation room. They then inform you that the following experiences are not unusual while in such a room: visual imagery, fantasies, special or unusual feelings, difficulties in concentration, hallucinations, and/or feelings of disorientation.
value_3: For 4 hours, you are left in the room. Afterwards, you are asked to trace a six-pointed star. While doing so, the researcher measures how often the traced line goes out of the border.

name: #01_p_ang
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for payment.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation room. They then inform you that the following experiences are not unusual while in such a room: visual imagery, fantasies, special or unusual feelings, difficulties in concentration, hallucinations, and/or feelings of disorientation.
value_3: For 4 hours, you are left in the room. Afterwards, you are asked to draw a variety of shapes described to you verbally. While doing so, the researcher measures how often the drawings have the incorrect angles.

name: #01_p_wor

value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation room. name: #01_p_rev
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for payment.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation room. They then inform you that the following experiences are not unusual while in such a room: visual imagery, fantasies, special or unusual feelings, difficulties in concentration, hallucinations, and/or feelings of disorientation.
value_3: For 4 hours, you are left in the room. Afterwards, you view an optical illusion and report how many times you succumb to the illusion.

name: #01_p_dig
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for payment.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation room. They then inform you that the following experiences are not unusual while in such a room: visual imagery, fantasies, special or unusual feelings, difficulties in concentration, hallucinations, and/or feelings of disorientation.
value_3: For 4 hours, you are left in the room. Afterwards, you complete a mental substitution task. The researcher assigns a symbol to specific digits, presents you with a list of digits, and measures how quickly you can  identify the symbol that corresponds to each digit.

name: #01_p_tap
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for payment.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation room. value_3: For 4 hours, you are left in the room. Afterwards, you complete a task measuring how many dots you can place in circles  in 30 seconds.

value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation room. name: #01_p_vis

name: #01_p_sim
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for payment.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation room. They then inform you that the following experiences are not unusual while in such a room: visual imagery, fantasies, special or unusual feelings, difficulties in concentration, hallucinations, and/or feelings of disorientation.
value_3: For 4 hours, you are left in the room. Afterwards, you view a series of simple shapes (e.g., a circle) from far away and are asked to report how many irregularities you detect.

name: #01_p_dur
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for payment.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation room. They then inform you that the following experiences are not unusual while in such a room: visual imagery, fantasies, special or unusual feelings, difficulties in concentration, hallucinations, and/or feelings of disorientation.
value_3: For 4 hours, you are left in the room. Afterwards, you are shown a spinning spiral before shifting your gaze to a stationary spiral. This creates the illusion that the stationary spiral is spinning, and you are asked to report how long this illusion persists.

name: #02_p_coo
value_1: Imagine that you are completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they expect exposure to the color purple to increase food intake.
value_3: You are presented with a bowl of cookies and asked to rate them on a sheet, which is purple. You are given 10 minutes to complete this task, wherein you can taste and eat as many cookies as you would like.

name: #03_p_swi
value_1: Imagine that you are completing an in-person study for €5 payment .
value_2: The researcher informs you that you will view an optical illusion wherein the orientation of the image appears to shift. After completing a measure of your ability to be hypnotized, the researcher says they believe people like you have a great ability to perceive a shift in the image.
value_3: You view the optical illusion for one minute, and you are asked to report how many times you see the image orientation shift.

name: #04_p_age

value_2: The researcher tells you that you will complete a challenging visual perception test while undergoing a brain stimulation procedure. They subsequently explain why they believe this brain stimulation will improve your performance.
value_3: You complete the visual perception test. Each time you make an error, you are asked to report whether your response was impacted by the brain stimulation.

name: #07_z_ver

value_3: While you stand at the bottom of the hill with the heavy backpack on, the researcher then asks you to verbally report how steep the hill is.

name: #08_p_pos

value_3: You are then shown a series of images on a computer screen. For each image, you are asked whether you had thoughts or feelings first.

name: #09_p_sat
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing a study as a volunteer or for extra credit.
value_2: The researcher asks you to imagine having a serious disagreement about a close friend. You then read several statements that are similar to the following: “Disagreeing means that our relationship is not good.” The researcher then tells you they expect that saying and believing these statements will make you feel better about your relationship.
value_3: After reading the statements, you are asked to report how satisfied you are with your relationship with the close friend.

value_3: After reading the statements, you are asked to report how satisfied you are with your relationship with the close friend.

name: #14_p_res
value_1: Imagine that you are working a free-lance job where you are paid to complete an online study.
value_2: The researcher tells you to imagine yourself as an HR officer tasked with sorting through resumes to determine which applicants should receive an interview for an entry-level sales position. They inform you that they anticipate you will be more likely to choose candidates with stereotypical White American names to receive an interview.
value_3: You are then presented with a resume, which contains either a stereotypically White American or African American name. You are then asked to indicate how willing you are to call the candidate for an interview.

name: #14_p_new
value_1: Imagine that you are working a free-lance job where you are paid to complete an online study.
value_2: The researcher tells you you will be indicating which type of news items you most prefer to read. They inform you that they anticipate you will be more likely to choose an article that favors your preferred political party because people tend to seek out information that is consistent with their personal views.
value_3: You are presented with a series of article headlines, each which is tagged as coming from either a pro-Republican, pro-Democrat, or non-partisan news source. For each series of headlines, you are asked to indicate which article you prefer.

value_3: You are presented with a series of article headlines, each which is tagged as coming from either a pro-Republican, pro-Democrat, or non-partisan news source. For each series of headlines, you are asked to indicate which article you prefer.

name: #15_p_mil

value_3: You are then presented with a hypothetical situation describing a country that is a threat to the U.S., including information about whether they are democratic or non-democratic.The researchers then ask you the extent to which you support military action against this country.

value_3: You are then presented with a hypothetical situation describing a country that is a threat to the U.S., including information about whether they are democratic or non-democratic. The researchers then ask you the extent to which you support military action against this country.

value_3: You are then presented with a case study of a hypothetical welfare recipient who is described as either lazy or unlucky. You are then asked to report the extent to which you support restricting access to social welfare.

name: #18_p_ale
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for course credit or £10.
value_2: The researcher tells you that previous research has indicated that chewing gum improves cognitive performance and mood. Their study aims to find out if these effects also exist with certain computer-based tasks.
value_3: They then run you through the trial twice, one while eating two pieces of gum, and once while not. They have you complete many tests, and ask you to report your alertness during each of the trials.

name: #18_n_hed
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for course credit or £10.
value_2: The researcher tells you that previous research has indicated that chewing gum impairs cognitive performance and mood. Their study aims to find out if these effects also exist with certain computer-based tasks.
value_3: They then run you through the trial twice, one while eating two pieces of gum, and once while not. They have you complete many tests, and ask you to report your hedonic tone during each of the trials.

name: #18_p_cat
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for course credit or £10.
value_2: The researcher tells you that previous research has indicated that chewing gum improves cognitive performance and mood. Their study aims to find out if these effects also exist with certain computer-based tasks.
value_3: They then run you through the trial twice, one while eating two pieces of gum, and once while not. They have you complete many tests, including a task in which two crosses appear on the screen, one of them turns into an A or a B (and the other a distraction), and you must quickly identify which letter appeared.

name: #20_p_vis
value_1: Imagine that you are completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: You enter the room, and the researcher tells you that anomalous experiences (unusual bodily sensations, seeing apparitions, hearing unusual sounds/voices, consciousness separates from body) have been previously found with the procedure you are about to complete.
value_3: For 45 minutes, you sit in a dimly lit chamber with a white noise track playing and stare at a mirror. You are then asked how often you experienced any visual apparitions.

name: #20_p_voc
value_1: Imagine that you are completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: You enter the room, and the researcher tells you that anomalous experiences (unusual bodily sensations, seeing apparitions, hearing unusual sounds/voices, consciousness separates from body) have been previously found with the procedure you are about to complete.
value_3: For 45 minutes, you sit in a dimly lit chamber with a white noise track playing and stare at a mirror. You are then asked how often you experienced any vocal anomalies (heard voices).

value_3: For 45 minutes, you sit in a dimly lit chamber with a white noise track playing and stare at a mirror. You are then asked how often you experienced any non-vocal anomalies (heard sounds other than voices).

name: #20_p_bod
value_1: Imagine that you are completing an in-person study as a volunteer.

value_3: For 45 minutes, you sit in a dimly lit chamber with a white noise track playing and stare at a mirror. You are then asked how often you had any out-of-body experiences.

name: #20_p_pre
value_1: Imagine that you are completing an in-person study as a volunteer.

name: #20_z_vis
value_1: Imagine that you are completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: You enter the room, and the researcher tells you that unusual experiences such as bodily sensations and changes in hearing/vision have been previously found with the procedure you are about to complete. However, they add that there are no consistencies in the type of experiences reported, so it’s okay to not experience anything.
value_3: For 45 minutes, you sit in a dimly lit chamber with a white noise track playing and stare at a mirror. You are then asked how often you experienced any visual apparitions.

name: #21_n_rat
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: You read a passage about a person completing a task alone and expressing thoughts like “I need not be successful in everything I do”. The researcher informs you that these statements will make you feel more anxious.
value_3: You complete a couple puzzles while repeating the statements from the passage. Afterwards, you report your anxiety-related symptoms.

name: #21_n_irr
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: You read a passage about a person completing a task alone and expressing thoughts like “I need to be successful in everything I do”. The researcher informs you that these statements will make you feel less anxious.
value_3: You complete a couple puzzles while repeating the statements from the passage. Afterwards, you report your anxiety-related symptoms.

name: #22_p_sim
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for extra course credit.
value_2: You are told that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation chamber. The researcher then informs you that it is not unusual to experience fantasies, visual imagery, difficulty concentrating, special/unusual feelings, and feelings of disorientation while in the sensory deprivation chamber.
value_3: You are put into a sensory deprivation chamber for four hours. Afterwards, you are shown a series of simple shapes (e.g., a circle) from far away and asked to report how many irregularities you detect.

name: #22_p_spi
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for extra course credit.
value_2: You are told that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation chamber. The researcher then informs you that it is not unusual to experience fantasies, visual imagery, difficulty concentrating, special/unusual feelings, and feelings of disorientation while in the sensory deprivation chamber.
value_3: You are put into a sensory deprivation chamber for four hours. Afterwards, you stare at a spinning spiral and then shift your vision to a stationary spiral. This creates the illusion that the stationary spiral is spinning, and you are asked to report how long this illusion persists.

name: #22_p_sen
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for extra course credit.
value_2: You are told that you will be placed in a sensory deprivation chamber. The researcher then informs you that it is not unusual to experience fantasies, visual imagery, difficulty concentrating, special/unusual feelings, and feelings of disorientation while in the sensory deprivation chamber.
value_3: You are put into a sensory deprivation chamber for four hours. Afterwards, you are asked to report whether you experienced each of the following: perceptual aberrations, intellectual dullness, unpleasantness, boredom, anxiety fears, spatial disorientation, restlessness, and irritability.

name: #23_p_rea
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: You enter the room and the researcher provides you with some information about the room’s lamp. Specifically, you receive a document from the lamp manufacturer that indicates their lamps improve performance and mood.
value_3: You sit in the room, with the lamp on, and subsequently complete a reading comprehension test.

name: #23_p_ari
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: You enter the room and the researcher provides you with some information about the room’s lamp. Specifically, you receive a document from the lamp manufacturer that indicates their lamps improve performance and mood.
value_3: You sit in the room, with the lamp on, and subsequently complete an arithmetic test.

name: #23_p_und
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: You enter the room and the researcher provides you with some information about the room’s lamp. Specifically, you receive a document from the lamp manufacturer that indicates their lamps improve performance and mood.
value_3: You sit in the room, with the lamp on, and subsequently complete a test of how quickly you can underline nouns.

name: #23_p_pos
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.

value_3: You sit in the room, with the lamp on, and subsequently self-report how positive you feel.

name: #23_z_rea

name: #25_p_hap
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will listen to happy music and informs you that people generally feel happy and exhilarated when listening to the music.
value_3: You listen to the happy music for 8-10 minutes and then self-report how happy you feel.

name: #25_n_hap
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will listen to happy music and informs you that, due to a social comparison effect, people generally feel the opposite emotion when listening to this music.
value_3: You listen to the happy music for 8-10 minutes and then self-report how happy you feel.

name: #26_p_gri
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study to satisfy a course requirement.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they believe that looking at the color pink increases muscle strength–and that recent research has supported their belief.
value_3: After being shown the pink panel for 1 minute, your grip strength is measured by a hand dynamometer that you pull on as hard as possible as you continue looking at the panel.

name: #26_n_gri
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study to satisfy a course requirement.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they believe that looking at the color pink decreases muscle strength–and that recent research has supported their belief.
value_3: After being shown the pink panel for 1 minute, your grip strength is measured by a hand dynamometer that you pull on as hard as possible as you continue looking at the panel.

name: #27_p_sal
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for extra course credit.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be asked to take a pill. They then inform you that participants who took the pill in previous studies experienced increased salivation.
value_3: You are given the pill and then some food to eat. Shortly afterwards, your salivation is measured.

name: #27_n_sal
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as volunteers or for extra course credit.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will be asked to take a pill. They then inform you that participants who took the pill in previous studies experienced decreased salivation.
value_3: You are given the pill and then some food to eat. Shortly afterwards, your salivation is measured.

name: #28_p_sim
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for extra course credit.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they believe you will be more attracted to people that are more similar to you. They ask that you behave in a manner consistent with this hypothesis.
value_3: You are presented with a stranger who is quite similar to you and asked to rate your attraction to them.

name: #28_p_dis
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for extra course credit.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they believe you will be more attracted to people that are more similar to you. They ask that you behave in a manner consistent with this hypothesis.
value_3: You are presented with a stranger who is quite dissimilar to you and asked to rate your attraction to them.

name: #29_n_dep
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for extra course credit.
value_2: The researcher tells you that you will read a variety of positive statements. They then inform you that research has shown that reading these positive statements will lead you to feel more depressed as a result of a so-called social comparison effect.
value_3: You are then told to read 60 statements progressing from neutral to elation in tone. Afterwards, you are asked to self-report how depressed you feel.

name: #30_p_puz
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study.
value_2: After solving puzzles for 10 minutes, the researcher informs you that, due to fatigue, they expect you to perform worse on a second set of puzzles.
value_3: You are then given the 10 minutes to solve as many puzzles as you can.

name: #31_p_sho
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study to satisfy a course requirement.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they expect your aggression to increase after watching an aggressive film.
value_3: After watching an aggressive film, you are asked to evaluate ideas for a promotional campaign developed by a second consenting participant. You are asked to deliver shocks that correspond to how good you think each idea is, and you control the intensity of the shock.

name: #31_n_sho
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study to satisfy a course requirement.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they expect your aggression to fall after watching an aggressive film because they expect the film to take all of the aggression out of you.
value_3: After watching an aggressive film, you are asked to evaluate ideas for a promotional campaign developed by a second consenting participant. You are asked to deliver shocks that correspond to how good you think each idea is, and you control the intensity of the shock.

name: #32_p_num
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for extra course credit.
value_2: You are told that you will be given 7 minutes to copy phone numbers. The researcher adjusts the lighting and informs you that they expect you to copy around 95 phone numbers given the lighting conditions.
value_3: The experimenter sets a timer, leaves the room, and you are given 7 minutes to copy a stack of phone numbers.

name: #32_n_num
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study for extra course credit.
value_2: You are told that you will be given 7 minutes to copy phone numbers. The researcher adjusts the lighting and informs you that they expect you to copy around 55 phone numbers given the lighting conditions.
value_3: The experimenter sets a timer, leaves the room, and you are given 7 minutes to copy a stack of phone numbers.

name: #33_p_beh
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student with a high fear of snakes who is completing an in-person study to fulfill a course requirement.
value_2: The researcher informs you that you will be completing a therapeutic treatment that will help reduce your fear of snakes.
value_3: For the next 3-4 weeks, you go back in twice for the therapeutic treatment, which consists of muscle relaxation and visualization exercises. Afterwards, you are placed in a room where you have a close-up encounter with a snake. Afterwards, the researcher assesses your fear of snakes.

name: #34_p_spa
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they are interested in the beneficial effects of listening to Mozart on test-taking capabilities.
value_3: While Mozart music is played, you are then asked to complete a test measuring spatial relations, wherein you see unfolding shapes and guess the corresponding folded pattern.

name: #34_p_ver
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they are interested in the beneficial effects of listening to Mozart on test-taking capabilities.
value_3: While Mozart music is played, you are then asked to complete a test measuring verbal reasoning, wherein you are asked to fill in the first and last word of example sentences.

name: #34_n_spa
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they are interested in the non-beneficial effects of listening to Mozart on test-taking capabilities.
value_3: While Mozart music is played, you are then asked to complete a test measuring spatial relations, wherein you see unfolding shapes and guess the corresponding folded pattern.

name: #34_n_ver
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they are interested in the non-beneficial effects of listening to Mozart on test-taking capabilities.
value_3: While Mozart music is played, you are then asked to complete a test measuring verbal reasoning, wherein you are asked to fill in the first and last word of example sentences.

name: #35_p_pus
value_1: Imagine that you are completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: The researcher informs you that, based on a growing amount of research, they believe that listening to Mozart’s music will increase your physical strength.
value_3: The experimenter plays Mozart music for ten minutes, shuts it off, and then asks you to complete as many pushups as possible in thirty seconds.

name: #35_n_pus
value_1: Imagine that you are completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: The researcher informs you that, based on a growing amount of research, they believe that listening to Mozart’s music will will decrease your physical strength.
value_3: The experimenter plays Mozart music for ten minutes, shuts it off, and then asks you to complete as many pushups as possible in thirty seconds.

name: #36_p_won
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they are interested in the beneficial effect of listening to Mozart on cognitive performance.
value_3: While Mozart music is played, you are then asked to complete a test measuring cognitive performance.

name: #36_n_won
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer or for course credit.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they are interested in the non-beneficial effect of listening to Mozart on cognitive performance.
value_3: While Mozart music is played, you are then asked to complete a test measuring cognitive performance.

name: #37_p_att
value_1: Imagine that you are a physical rehabilitative hospital patient who is completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: The researcher informs you that they expect your attitudes towards the hospital and yourself to change due to your 4-6 week hospital stay for physical rehabilitative therapy.
value_3: After the hospital stay, they ask you whether your attitudes have changed.

name: #38_p_err
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: The researcher informs you that you will be looking at a new screen for commercial airlines. They then inform you that they believe the screen does not meet certain legibility requirements. They add that they thus expect you to make many reading errors while viewing the screen.
value_3: You are then shown the screen in a dark room and asked to identify several sets of letters.

name: #38_n_err
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing an in-person study as a volunteer.
value_2: The researcher informs you that you will be looking at a new screen for commercial airlines. They then inform you that they believe the screen meets, and even exceed, certain legibility requirements. They add that they thus expect you to make only a few reading errors while viewing the screen.
value_3: You are then shown the screen in a dark room and asked to identify several sets of letters.

name: #39_p_sat
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing a study as volunteers or for extra credit.
value_2: The researcher asks you to imagine having a serious disagreement about a romantic partner or close friend. You then read several statements that are similar to the following: “Disagreeing means that our relationship is not good.” The researcher then tells you they expect that saying and believing these statements will make you feel better about your relationship.
value_3: After reading the statements, you are asked to report how satisfied you are with your relationship with the close friend.

name: #39_n_sat
value_1: Imagine that you are a university student completing a study as volunteers or for extra credit.
value_2: The researcher asks you to imagine having a serious disagreement about a close friend. You then read several statements that are similar to the following: “Disagreeing does not mean that our relationship is not good.” The researcher then tells you they expect that saying and believing these statements will make you feel worse about your relationship.
value_3: After reading the statements, you are asked to report how satisfied you are with your relationship with the close friend.
